 request:                                        
            Board Bill No. 164                   
      An ordinance recommended by the Board      
 of Public Service to conditionally vacate above 
 surface, surface and sub-surface rights for     
vehicle, equestrian and pedestrian travel in the   
20 foot wide north/south alley in City Block       
1450E as bounded by Halliday, Compton,             
Pestalozzi and Virginia in the City of St. Louis,  
Missouri, as hereinafter described, in             
accordance with Charter authority, and in          
conformity with Section l4 of Article XXI of       
the Charter and imposing certain conditions        
on such vacation.                                  
Board Member Roddy introduced by request:          
           Board Bill No. 165                      
      An ordinance approving a blighting study     
and redevelopment plan dated July 26, 2011         
for the 4207 Arco Ave. Redevelopment Area          
(as further defined herein, the "Plan") after      
finding that said Redevelopment Area ("Area")      
is blighted as defined in Section 99.320 of the    
Revised Statutes of Missouri, as amended (the      
"Statute" being Sections 99.300 to 99.715          
RSMo inclusive, as amended); containing a          
description of the boundaries of the Area in       
the City of St. Louis ("City"), attached hereto    
and incorporated herein as Attachment "A",         
finding that redevelopment and rehabilitation      
of the Area is in the interest of the public       
health, safety, morals and general welfare of      
the people of the City; approving the Plan         
attached hereto and incorporated herein as         
Attachment "B", pursuant to Section 99.430         
RSMo, as amended; finding that there is a          
feasible financial plan for the redevelopment      
of the Area which affords maximum                  
opportunity for redevelopment of the Area          
by private enterprise; finding that no property    
in the Area may be acquired by the Land            
Clearance for Redevelopment Authority of the       
City of St. Louis ("LCRA"), a public body          
corporate and politic created under Missouri       
law, through the exercise of eminent domain;       
finding that none of the property within the       
Area is occupied, but if it should become          
occupied the Redeveloper(s) (as defined            
herein) shall be responsible for providing         
relocation assistance pursuant to the Plan to      
any eligible occupants displaced as a result of    
implementation of the Plan; finding that           
financial aid may be necessary to enable the       
Area to be redeveloped in accordance with          
the Plan; finding that there shall be available    
up to a ten (10) year real estate tax abatement;   
and pledging cooperation of this St. Louis         
Board of Aldermen ("Board") and requesting         
various officials, departments, boards and         
agencies of the City to cooperate and to           
exercise their respective powers in a manner       
consistent with the Plan; and containing a         
severability clause.

      None.                                    
 BOARD BILLS FOR PERFECTION                    
       Ms. Krewson moved that Board Bill No.   
 107 before the Board for perfection, be       
 perfected as reported out of Committee with   
 its recommendation "Do Pass".                 
      Seconded by Ms. Florida.                 
      Ms. Krewson withdrew her motion and      
 requested that Board Bill No. 107 be placed   
 on the Board Bills for Perfection - Informal  
 Calendar.                                     
          THIRD READING                        
        CONSENT CALENDAR                       
      None.                                    
   THIRD READING, REPORT OF                    
 THE ENGROSSMENT COMMITTEE                     
      AND FINAL PASSAGE                        
        OF BOARD BILLS                         
      Board of Aldermen, Committee Report,     
 St. Louis, September 16, 2011.                
      To the President of the Board of         
 Aldermen:                                     
      The Committee on Engrossed and           
 Enrolled Bills to whom was referred the       
 following Board Bills report that they have   
 considered the same and they are truly        
 engrossed.                                    
     Ms. Ford-Griffin moved to reconsider      
 Board Bill No. 100 (Committee Substitute).    
      Seconded by Ms. Florida.                 
      Carried by the following vote:           
      Ayes: Troupe, Flowers, Bosley, Moore,    
 Ford-Griffin, Triplett, Conway, Ortmann,      
 Vollmer, Villa, Wessels, Howard, Florida,     
 Roddy, Kennedy, Davis, French, Boyd,          
 Vaccaro, Ogilvie, Cohn, Williamson, Carter,   
 Krewson and President Reed. 25                
      Noes: 0                                  
      Present: 0                               
          Board Bill No. 100                   
        (Committee Substitute)                 
       An ordinance authorizing and directing  
 the Mayor and Comptroller of the City of St.  
 Louis to execute, upon receipt of and in      
 consideration of the sum of One Hundred       
 Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00) and other      
 good and valuable consideration, a Quit Claim 
 Deed to remise, release and forever quit-claim
 unto Grace Hill Neighborhood Health Centers,  
 Inc., a Missouri non-profit corporation,      
 certain City-owned property located in City   
 Block 569, which property is known as 1717    
 Biddle Street, St. Louis, Missouri 63106      
 (Assessor's Records 1704-1743 Biddle), and    
 containing an emergency clause.               
       Ms. Ford-Griffin requested that Board   
 Bill No. 100 (Committee Substitute) be placed 
 on the Board Bills for Perfection - Informal  
 Calendar.                                     
     Ms. Ford-Griffin moved to reconsider      
 Board Bill No. 101 (Committee Substitute).    
      Seconded by Mr. Williamson.              
      Carried by the following vote:           
      Ayes: Troupe, Flowers, Bosley, Moore,    
 Ford-Griffin, Triplett, Conway, Ortmann,      
 Vollmer, Villa, Wessels, Howard, Florida,     
 Roddy, Kennedy, Davis, French, Boyd,          
 Vaccaro, Ogilvie, Cohn, Williamson, Carter,   
 Krewson and President Reed. 25                
     Noes: 0                                    
     Present: 0                                 
         Board Bill No. 101                     
       (Committee Substitute)                   
      An ordinance authorizing and directing    
the Mayor and Comptroller of the City of St.    
Louis to execute, upon receipt of and in        
consideration of the sum of One Hundred         
Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00) and other        
good and valuable consideration, a Quit Claim   
Deed to remise, release and forever quit-claim  
unto Grace Hill Neighborhood Health Centers,    
Inc., a Missouri non-profit corporation,        
certain City-owned property located in City     
Block 1335, which property is known as 2220     
Lemp Avenue, St. Louis, Missouri 63104          
(Assessor's Records 2220 Lemp), and             
containing an emergency clause.                 
      Ms. Ford-Griffin requested that Board     
Bill No. 101 (Committee Substitute) be placed   
on the Board Bills for Perfection - Informal    
Calendar.                                       
     Alderman Vollmer                           
     Chairman of the Committee                  
        REPORT OF THE                           
    ENROLLMENT COMMITTEE                        
     None.                                      
    COURTESY RESOLUTIONS                        
      CONSENT CALENDAR                          
      President Reed introduced Resolutions     
No. 145 through 198 and 201 and the Clerk       
was instructed to read same.                    
          Resolution No. 145                    
           JOURNEY OF HOPE                      
      WHEREAS, the Pi Kappa Phi Fraternity      
founded "Push America" with the intention       
of providing service and education to promote   
a greater understanding of persons with         
disabilities; and                               
     WHEREAS, the Journey of Hope team,         
consisting of members of Pi Kappa Phi           
Fraternity, is going the extra mile for people  
with disabilities; and                          
     WHEREAS, the Journey of Hope team          
began a bicycle trip on June 4, 2011, leaving   
Seattle, Washington, and will arrive in         
Washington, D.C. on August 13, 2011,            
traveling over 4000 miles; and                  
     WHEREAS, the team has cycled from          
city to city carrying their message of          
acceptance and understanding to the hearts      
and homes of people across the United States;   
and                                             
     WHEREAS, now completing their              
nation-wide trek, the team has raised more      
than $500,000 which will further the cause of   
 "Push America."                                       
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                              
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of                  
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our            
 deliberations to recognize and thank the              
 Journey of Hope team who has provided                 
 untiring dedication to their cause and we             
 further direct the Clerk of this Board to spread      
 a copy of this Resolution across the minutes          
 of these proceedings and to prepare a                 
 commemorative copy to the end that it may             
 be presented to our honoree at a time and             
 place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.              
 Introduced on the 23rd day of July, 2011 by:          
 Honorable Lewis E. Reed, President, Board ofAldermen  
            Resolution No. 146                         
          Rev. John Watson Sr.                         
      WHEREAS, Rev. John Watson Sr. is a               
 native of St. Louis. He received his formal           
 education through the St. Louis Public Schools        
 System. In addition, he attended Washington           
 Technical High School and later graduated from        
 Tucker Business College. He received                  
 theological training from Concordia Seminary          
 in Clayton, Missouri. His leadership abilities        
 evolved during his service in the United States       
 Armed Forces; and                                     
       WHEREAS, Rev. Watson accepted his               
 call to the ministry in 1960. He has served           
 and continues to serve God, Church and                
 community in various capacities and ways              
 such as: Jurisdictional Chair of the Taskforce,       
 Chairman for Installation of Bishop R. J. Ward,       
 State Secretary under the late Bishop Turner,         
 Superintendent of Gus Martian District,               
 Present Superintendent Emeritus, Special              
 Counselor to Bishop, and a member of the St.          
 Louis Ministerial Alliance. His contributions         
 to the church on the national, state, and local       
 level have earned him the respect of countless        
 church elders, pastors, missionaries, and             
 others; and                                           
       WHEREAS, Rev. Watson is a radio                 
 gospel preacher. He can be heard on WGNU              
 920 every Sunday night bringing spiritual             
 insight, healing, and deliverance to the St. Louis    
 community. His Ministry spans 38 years. In            
 1973, he was called to the membership of Zion         
 Temple with Maple Temple Church. Under                
 his leadership, the Maple Temple Church               
 continued to grow and impact the surrounding          
 community; and                                        
      WHEREAS,           Pastor     Watson             
 implemented programs and events that                  
 improved the quality of life for the                  
 neighborhood and surrounding area such as: a          
 back to school festival for the youth, non            
 violent marches, victims of crime advocacy            
 group meetings, radio announcement of                 
 community events and notices, and a                
 appointed community liaison to establish a         
 program that would serve the Academy area.         
 Out of this initiative, a partnership was          
 established between the Maple Temple               
 Church and the Academy-Sherman Park                
 Neighborhood Association. The church was           
 named the headquarters of the Academy-             
 Sherman Park Neighborhood Association              
 where on going planning, communication, and        
 implementation of community development            
 takes place between the church, area residents,    
 city officials, state official, and other          
 community leaders; and                             
       WHEREAS, Rev. John Watson Sr. has            
 been a blessing to the members of the church,      
 the national church, the Academy community,        
 and the entire St. Louis area.                     
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                          
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of               
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our         
 deliberations to recognize the many                
 achievements of Rev. John Watson Sr. and we        
 direct the Clerk of this Board to spread a copy    
 of this Resolution across the minutes of these     
 proceedings and to prepare a commemorative         
 copy to the end that it may be presented to        
 our honoree at a time and place deemed             
 appropriate by the Sponsor.                        
 Introduced on the 13th day of July, 2011 by:       
 Honorable Frank Williamson, Alderman 26th Ward     
            Resolution No. 147                      
          Harry Thurston Jones                      
       WHEREAS, Harry Thurston Jones                
 aspired to become a businessman at an early        
 age. He opened his own snow cone business          
 when he was 16 years old in the Ville area of      
 the city. Upon gradation from McBride High         
 School, this business venture enabled him to       
 attend Moler Barber School; and                    
       WHEREAS, in 1958, he steadfastly             
 maintained a laser-like focus on opening           
 another business, now known as Harry's             
 Barber Service located at 4619 Dr Martin           
 Luther King Drive, despite the many barriers       
 that he encountered. He knew that while it         
 was one thing to start a small business; it was    
 another to conceptualize an idea and the see it    
 transform into a successful business. His can-     
 do spirit became contagious, self reinforcing      
 and unstoppable. As a result of his dedication,    
 he has successfully remained in business for       
 more than 50 years; and                            
       WHEREAS, Harry was able to achieve           
 his goal by high goal work performance, work       
 skills, personal motivation, and social            
 networking with diverse, skilled, blue and         
 white collar individuals. His reputation           
 attracted celebrities, politicians, city officials,
city and county police officers, and news         
media. He was contacted by Crimestoppers          
to film a reenactment of the crime scene at his   
shop during regular work hours. This was          
later aired on Channel 4 News; and                
      WHEREAS, he knew that it was                
important to give back to the community. He       
accomplished this by mentoring young              
children and young adults. Many of them are       
now successful adults and remain loyal            
customers to this date. He has two customers      
that have remained loyal to him since 1958.       
Harry has sponsored annual cork ball              
tournaments for many years, as a way of           
connecting to the city community and getting      
them involved in city projects. He has also       
sponsored baseball teams; and                     
      WHEREAS, he met his wife Terrye, a          
native of Texas, while she was attending SIC-     
C. She is retired nurse of 30 years. They         
have one daughter, Kameron, who is an             
educator in the public school system with 21      
years experience. His granddaughter, Katelyn      
is currently an honor roll student at Incarnate   
Word Academy; and                                 
      WHEREAS, he always stressed the             
importance of good education and work ethics      
to his daughter and granddaughter at a very       
young age. Other family members include his       
mother, sister, son-in-law, nieces, nephews,      
cousins, and an aunt.                             
     NOW THEREFORE BE IT                          
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
deliberations to recognize Harry Thurston         
Jones and we wish him continued success,          
achievement and accomplishment and we             
further direct the Clerk of this Board to spread  
a copy of this Resolution across the minutes      
of these proceedings and to prepare a             
commemorative copy to the end that it may         
be presented to our honoree at a time and         
place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.          
Introduced on the 12th day of July, 2011 by:      
Honorable Samuel L. Moore,Alderman 4th Ward       
          Resolution No. 148                      
               Ernie Isley                        
     WHEREAS, Ernie Isley was reared in           
Cincinnati, where his older brothers formed       
The Isley Brothers, first as a gospel group,      
then as a secular-singing group, until 1960       
when he and his family moved to Englewood,        
New Jersey; and                                   
      WHEREAS, after befriending Jimi             
Hendrix, who was one of the touring guitarists    
for his brothers and lived at the Isleys' home    
for several years, and after being influenced     
by Jose Feliciano's version of The Doors'         
 "Light My Fire", Isley trained himself to be a   
 guitarist; and                                   
       WHEREAS, his first live gig as a member    
 of his brothers' band, at age 14, was as a       
 drummer in 1966; two years later he did his      
 first professional recording, playing bass on    
 the Isleys' breakthrough funk smash, "It's       
 Your Thing", released in 1969. He got his first  
 guitar in October, 1968. He played electric      
 and acoustic guitar, and drums in the group's    
 early 1970s albums, Get Into Something,          
 Givin' It Back and Brother, Brother, Brother,    
 before fully joining the Isley Brothers fold in  
 1973, becoming a songwriter and multi-           
 instrumentalist playing both acoustic and        
 electric guitar, drums and percussion; and       
       WHEREAS, he is a songwriter writing        
 many of the hits the Isley Brothers are known    
 for, including "Fight the Power Pts. 1 & 2",     
 "Harvest for the World", "Voyage to Atlantis",   
 "At Your Best, You are Love", "Footsteps in      
 the Dark", "Brown Eyed Girl", among others,      
 and "Take Me to the Next Phase" (co-written      
 with brother Marvin and brother-in-law           
 Chris), "That Lady" (co-written with Chris),     
 and "Between The Sheets (co-written with         
 Marvin)", "For the Love of You" (first and       
 third verses, second verse by Chris) among       
 many others. In 1984, Ernie, Marvin and Chris    
 formed group, Isley-Jasper-Isley, scoring with   
 their number one album, Caravan of Love; and     
       WHEREAS, in 1990, Ernie Isley              
 released his first solo album, High Wire. In     
 the same year he recorded a cover version of     
 the The Cars' "Let's Go" for the compilation     
 album, Rubaiyat. The next year, he re-joined     
 Ronald and Marvin on tour and in the studio;     
 and                                              
     WHEREAS, he was inducted into the            
 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1992; and          
       WHEREAS, he was a musician on the          
 Janet Jackson album, Discipline, on the tracks   
 "Never Letchu Go" and "The 1".                   
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                         
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of             
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our       
 deliberations to recognize Ernie Isley and we    
 wish him continued success, achievement and      
 accomplishment and we further direct the         
 Clerk of this Board to spread a copy of this     
 Resolution across the minutes of these           
 proceedings and to prepare a commemorative       
 copy to the end that it may be presented to      
 our honoree at a time and place deemed           
 appropriate by the Sponsor.                      
 Introduced on the 8th of July, 2011 by:          
 Honorable Marlene Davis,Alderwoman 19th Ward     
           Resolution No. 149                    
            GregAlan Williams                    
      WHEREAS, GregAlan Williams is an           
 Emmy-award winning TV and film star, who        
 boasts roles on a wide variety of Hollywood     
 presentations, such as Baywatch, The West       
 Wing, The District, The Sopranos, The Game,     
 Army Wives, Meet the Browns, Murder She         
 Wrote, Above the Law, Remember the Titans,      
 and currently the cable TV series, Necessary    
 Roughness; and                                  
      WHEREAS, this seasoned and                 
 acclaimed actor has written and will star in his
 own powerful one-man show, The Life and         
 Times of Deacon A. L. Wiley, a close and        
 authentic look at the experiences of African    
 Americans at the turn-of the century; and       
      WHEREAS, GregAlan is the recipient         
 of many awards and honors, including his        
 rescue of a Japanese American during the 1992   
 unrest in Los Angeles following the beating of  
 motorist, Rodney King; and                      
       WHEREAS, GregAlan has worked              
 diligently to help African-American students    
 attending Historically Black Colleges and       
 Universities by conducting workshops and        
 classes to inspire them to succeed; and will    
 conduct a workshop at Harris-Stowe State        
 University to support the students of the       
 Harris-Stowe Players; and                       
      WHEREAS, GregAlan is a popular             
 speaker at many local schools and               
 organizations, he also speaks on behalf of      
 many human rights groups including the Anti-    
 Defamation League, Facing History and           
 Ourselves, The American Federation of           
 Teachers and the Elie Weisel Foundation for     
 Humanity; and                                   
       WHEREAS, GregAlan Williams is             
 heading to the St. Louis stage at Harris-Stowe  
 State University's Emerson Performance          
 Center Theater on Saturday, July 30, 2011 at    
 7 pm to perform for the benefit of at-risk      
 youth and children served by three faith-based  
 organizations in the St. Louis area; namely,    
 Jamison Memorial Human Resource &               
 Development Agency, St. John Community          
 Improvement Corporation, and HopeBUILD,         
 along with the College of Education,            
 Department of Social & Behavioral Sciences      
 and the Harris-Stowe Players of Harris-Stowe    
 State University.                               
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                        
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of            
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our      
 deliberations to recognize GregAlan Williams    
 and we wish him continued success,              
 achievement and accomplishment, and we          
 further direct the Clerk of this Board to spread
a copy of this Resolution across the minutes      
of these proceedings and to prepare a             
commemorative copy to the end that it may         
be presented to our honoree at a time and         
place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.          
Introduced on the 22nd of July, 2011 by:          
Honorable Marlene Davis,Alderwoman 19th Ward      
          Resolution No. 150                      
         Ronald "Butch" Lewis                     
     WHEREAS, we pause in our                     
deliberations to recognize the untimely passing   
Ronald "Butch" Lewis; and                         
      WHEREAS, Ronald "Butch" Lewis, the          
colorful boxing promoter, had just celebrated     
his birthday on June 26, 2011 bringing it in      
with style by hosting a private affair on         
Delaware's Bethany Beach has passed away          
Saturday, July 23, 2011 at the age of 65 from     
a massive heart attack; and                       
       WHEREAS, Ronald "Butch" Lewis,             
who was responsible for several multi-million     
dollar prizefights involving Muhammad Ali,        
Joe Frazier, Mike Tyson, Larry Holmes, and        
Michael and Leon Spinks (whom he                  
managed). He promoted the Michael Spinks-         
Mike Tyson fight in 1988 that ended with a        
first round knock of Spinks, who earned more      
than $13 million for the fight; and               
     WHEREAS, he began his career in              
boxing in the 1970s, but later branched into      
music and entertainment; and                      
      WHEREAS, known for his unique style         
of dress, featuring the "shirtless tuxedo look,"  
Lewis appeared in several boxing                  
documentaries, produced the pay-per-event,        
"James Brown: Living in America" and              
episodes of the Showtime series, "Linc's," and    
was executive producer of the film, Once          
Upon A Time When We Were Colored; and             
      WHEREAS, in 2008, Lewis tried his           
hand at the music industry, partnering with       
Def Jam Records to create the label, Voicez.      
Last year, IMG Worldwide announced a joint        
talent management venture with Butch Lewis        
Productions; and                                  
      WHEREAS, a philanthropist, Lewis            
started a foundation that sent underprivileged    
students to college and provided Christmas        
gifts to needy Harlem children. During the        
early 1990's, he worked closely with Nelson       
Mandela in the anti-apartheid movement in         
South Africa; and                                 
     WHEREAS, the former car salesman             
from Philadelphia received an honorary            
doctorate and Candle Award in Business and        
Entertainment from Morehouse College. He          
was also recognized by the state of Delaware,     
 where he lived at the end of his life, with       
 "Butch Lewis Day" honors for his many             
 charitable contributions; and                     
     WHEREAS, before the Zab Judah-Amir            
 Khan fight in Las Vegas on Saturday, July 23,     
 2011, Lewis was honored by ring announcer         
 Michael Buffer and given a 10-bell count; and     
       WHEREAS, along with his family, a long      
 list of close friends are left to mourn Ronald    
 "Butch" Lewis.                                    
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                         
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
 the City of St. Louis that we pause to            
 remember the life of Ronald "Butch" Lewis         
 and we join with his many friends in              
 expressing our sorrow at his passing, and we      
 further direct the Clerk of this Board to spread  
 a copy of this Resolution across the minutes      
 of these proceedings and to prepare a memorial    
 copy for presentation to the Lewis family, at     
 a time and place deemed appropriate by the        
 Sponsor.                                          
 Introduced on the 27th day of July, 2011 by:      
 Honorable Samuel L. MooreAlderman 4th Ward        
           Resolution No. 151                      
                Chuck Berry                        
       WHEREAS, Charles Edward Anderson            
 "Chuck" Berry was born October 18, 1926           
 into a middle class family in Saint Louis,        
 Missouri. Berry settled into married life and     
 worked at an automobile assembly plant. By        
 early 1953, influenced by the guitar riffs and    
 showmanship techniques of blues player T-         
 Bone Walker; and                                  
      WHEREAS, Berry had an interest in            
 music from an early age and gave his first        
 public performance at Summer High School.         
 His break came when he traveled to Chicago        
 in May, 1955 and met Muddy Waters, who            
 suggested that he contact Leonard Chess of        
 Chess Records; and                                
       WHEREAS, with Chess he recorded             
 "Maybellene"-Berry's adaptation of the            
 country song "Ida Red" which sold over a          
 million copies, reaching #1 on Billboard's        
 Rhythm and Blues chart. By the end of the         
 1950s, Berry was an established star with         
 several hit records and film appearances to       
 his name as well as a lucrative touring career.   
 He had also established his own St. Louis-        
 based nightclub, called Berry's Club              
 Bandstand; and                                    
      WHEREAS, as American guitarist,              
 singer, and songwriter, and one of the pioneers   
 of Rock and Roll music Chuck Berry had            
 several songs which hit it big. Just to name a    
 few: "Roll Over Beethoven", "Rock and Roll        
 Music", and "Johnny B. Goode". Chuck              
 Berry refined and developed rhythm and blues        
 into the major elements that made rock and          
 roll distinctive, with lyrics focusing on teen      
 life and consumerism; and                           
       WHEREAS, Berry was among the first            
 musicians to be inducted into the Rock and          
 Roll Hall of Fame on its opening in 1986,           
 with the comment that he "laid the groundwork       
 for not only a rock and roll sound but a rock       
 and roll stance." Berry is included in several      
 Rolling Stone "Greatest of All Time" lists,         
 including being ranked fifth on their 2004 list     
 of the 100 Greatest Artists of All Time. Today,     
 at the age of 84 - Berry continues to play live.    
 Congratulations on your many honors and             
 may God continue to bless you.                      
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                            
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of                
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our          
 deliberations to recognize Charles Edward           
 Anderson "Chuck" Berry and we thank him             
 for his many contributions to not only the          
 City of St. Louis, but to the world and we          
 further direct the Clerk of this Board to spread    
 a copy of this Resolution across the minutes        
 of these proceedings and to prepare a               
 commemorative copy to the end that it may           
 be presented to our honoree at a time and           
 place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.            
 Introduced on the 28th of July, 2011 by:            
 Honorable Samuel L. MooreAlderman 4th Ward          
 Honorable Lewis E. Reed, President, Board ofAldermen
            Resolution No. 152                       
      Honoring Mrs. Bessie Pearl                     
           Robinson-Foreman                          
      WHEREAS, Bessie Pearl Robinson was             
 born on July 28, 1931 and has attained the age      
 of four score on this day in 2011; and              
       WHEREAS, Bessie Pearl Robinson was            
 the youngest of 11 children born to Robert          
 Lee and Pearl Mada Robinson in Okolona,             
 Mississippi and relocated to St. Louis with         
 her family shortly thereafter; and                  
      WHEREAS, Bessie Pearl Robinson                 
 received her formal education in the St. Louis      
 Public Schools graduating from Banneker             
 Elementary School and Sumner High School;           
 and                                                 
      WHEREAS, Bessie Pearl Robinson                 
 married the late Woodrow Foreman and                
 became the proud mother of Faye M. Foreman          
 and Eric M. Foreman; and                            
      WHEREAS, Bessie Pearl Robinson-                
 Foreman completed her post secondary                
 education at Stowe Teachers College and             
 Harris Teachers College with advanced degrees       
 from Webster University and served as a             
 classroom and music teacher for 40 years            
before retiring from the St. Louis Public         
Schools in June 2000; and                         
      WHEREAS, Bessie Pearl Robinson-             
Foreman has tirelessly served God through         
song and deeds at the Berean Seventh Day          
Adventist Church in St. Louis, MO and is a        
lifelong member who continues to serve in         
numerous capacities; and                          
      WHEREAS, Bessie Pearl Robinson-             
Foreman actively works with Block Unit 365        
in the 5000-5200 blocks of Lotus Avenue in        
St. Louis, Mo where she resides and witnesses     
to neighbors, passersby, and anyone who will      
listen to testimony regarding God's Goodness;     
and                                               
     WHEREAS, the family, friends, and            
community of Bessie Pearl Robinson-               
Foreman salute and pay tribute to her on this     
her 80th Birthday Celebration; and                
     WHEREAS, the City of St. Louis               
wishes to honor, thank, and support our           
senior life-long resident who has been an         
outstanding citizen and role model.               
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                         
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
deliberations to recognize and congratulate       
Bessie Pearl Robinson-Foreman on her 80th         
birthday and for her many contributions to        
her family, church, community and to the City     
of St. Louis and by adoption of this resolution   
wish to join in the festivities honoring her and  
we further direct the Clerk of this Board to      
spread a copy of this Resolution across the       
minutes of these proceedings and to prepare a     
commemorative copy to the end that it may         
be presented to our honoree at a time and         
place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.          
Introduced on the 28th day of July, 2011 by:      
HonorableTerry KennedyAlderman 18th Ward          
          Resolution No. 153                      
            Gil Scott-Heron                       
     WHEREAS, Poet, Singer, Activist,             
Musician, Author, Visionary Gil Scott-Heron       
whose amalgam of jazz, blues, African music,      
spoken word poetry was uniquely his own           
was born on April 1, 1949 in Chicago; and         
      WHEREAS, Gil Scott-Heron looked             
back to the spirituals and work songs, and        
demonstrated like Leadbelly, and Guthrie that     
popular music could be effective as a vehicle     
for serious ideas as a broadside of political     
speech including when he helped to raise          
awareness about the era of Apartheid in South     
Africa with his revolutionary, political          
socially conscious song, "What's the Word,        
Johannesburg"; and                                
       WHEREAS, Gil Scott-Heron was                 
 fiercely proud to be African American and          
 never feared controversy, being greatly            
 influenced by poet Langston Hughes, he forged      
 his cadence on his great subject of the everyday   
 struggle of the poor and dispossessed              
 confronting poverty, addiction, government         
 neglect, and sheer unmotivated cruelty-            
 spinning all he had seen into poetry and song;     
 and                                                
       WHEREAS, Gil Scott-Heron recorded            
 over 20 albums which included such classics        
 as "Winter in America", Rivers of My Fathers,      
 and "The Bottle" which became a Billboard          
 chart success, moreover, his most famous work      
 "The Revolution Will Not Be Televised", and        
 additionally, his enormous influence on hip-       
 hop is undeniable, and is the template for         
 many rappers with social conscience including      
 De La Soul, Chuck D (Public Enemy), Dr.            
 Dre, RBX, KRS-One, and Kanye West; and             
       WHEREAS, Gil Scott-Heron's early             
 recordings were consistent with the                
 conventions of jazz poetry with movement           
 that sought to bring the spontaneity of live       
 performance to the reading of verse, he            
 combined social and political commentary           
 with spoken words, and musical grooves             
 exhibiting superior skills for being able to put   
 rhythm and opinion and expressive thought          
 with a sense of voice and musicality together;     
 and                                                
      WHEREAS, Gil Scott-Heron provides             
 a source of profound inspiration to people         
 world-wide interested in the spoken word and       
 poetry genre ,including artists in St. Louis,      
 Missouri; and                                      
       WHEREAS, The HOTBOX Virtualclub              
 STL in St. Louis, Missouri is proud to honor       
 Gil Scott-Heron for the tremendous impact          
 of his legacy as a world class performing artist   
 who is considered one of the "the Fathers of       
 the spoken word movement " that gave               
 "voice" to the "voiceless".                        
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                          
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of               
 the City of St. Louis that we happily pause in     
 our deliberations to recognize the many            
 contributions of poet Gil Scott-Heron and          
 congratulate Hotbox on honoring such a             
 distinguished artist and by adoption of this       
 resolution we wish to join all others in honoring  
 Mr. Heron and we further direct the Clerk of       
 this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution     
 across the permanent rolls of this Board and       
 to prepare a commemorative copy to the end         
 that it may be presented to our honoree at a       
 time and place deemed appropriate by the           
 Sponsor.                                           
 Introduced on the 28th day of July, 2011 by:       
 Honorable Terry KennedyAlderman 18th Ward       
           Resolution No. 154                    
     Police Officer Michael Missel               
            DSN 8164 and                         
        Probationary Police Officer              
               Randy Hays 1250                   
        WHEREAS, PO Mike Missel DSN,             
 8164 and PPO Randy Hays, DSN 1250, who          
 is in field training, during this month worked  
 as a team and they arrested twelve individuals. 
 Of those twelve arrests, two were of particular 
 interest; and                                   
        WHEREAS, the first incident was on 1-    
 23-2011, occurring at 4439 Greer documented     
 under complaint number 11-004131. PO            
 Missel and Hays conducted a traffic stop that   
 resulted in a narcotics arrest with the results 
 still pending from the lab; and                 
       WHEREAS, the second incident              
 occurred on 1-26-2011 on Newberry Terrace,      
 documented under complaint number 11-           
 004663. The Officers conducted a pedestrian     
 check at the listed location and the offender   
 tried to run from the Officers. The Officers    
 grabbed the offender who began resisting with   
 the Officers. The Officers were able to place   
 handcuffs on the Offender who was armed         
 with a .38 caliber revolver. The Offender was   
 a convicted felon and warrants were, "Issued"   
 for "Felon in Possession of a Firearm."; and    
      WHEREAS, in addition to the twelve         
 arrests, the Officers issued 40 traffic         
 summonses in January.                           
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                        
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of            
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our      
 deliberations to recognize Police Officer       
 Michael Missel DSN 8164 and Probationary        
 Police Officer Randy Hays 1250 and we thank     
 them for their many contributions to not only   
 the City of St. Louis, but to the world and we  
 further direct the Clerk of this Board to spread
 a copy of this Resolution across the minutes    
 of these proceedings and to prepare a           
 commemorative copy to the end that it may       
 be presented to our honoree at a time and       
 place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.        
 Introduced on the 29th of July, 2011 by:        
 Honorable Samuel L. MooreAlderman 4th Ward      
           Resolution No. 155                    
    Police Officer Julie Reynolds                
              DSN 7591                           
           and Police Officer                    
    Mathew Wieczorek DSN 8039                    
      WHEREAS, PO Julie Reynolds DSN             
 7591 and PO Mathew Wieczorek DSN 8039           
 were nominated as Eighth District Officer of    
 the Month for the month of Febraury; and        
     WHEREAS, during the Month of                 
February, the Officers working as a team made     
several Felony arrests for various charges.       
These are documented under Complaint              
numbers 11-005672, 11-007178, 11-009335,          
and 11-009735. They also conducted a              
thorough investigation that culminated into       
two Search Warrants being obtained and a large    
amount of narcotics was seized; and               
      WHEREAS, these are documented per           
complaint numbers 11-008798 and 11-               
003933. They also affected two additional         
arrests for Parole Violation and several active   
Warrants; and                                     
       WHEREAS, the officers conducted            
numerous traffic stops with twenty traffic        
summons issued. The Officers conducted all        
this activity while assigned to a radio car and   
still handled several calls for service; and      
      WHEREAS, the Officers have a good           
work ethic and always keep a positive attitude.   
Both Officers have good working relationships     
with their fellow Officers and work well with     
the public.                                       
     NOW THEREFORE BE IT                          
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
deliberations to recognize Police Officer Julie   
Reynolds DSN 7591 and Police Officer              
Mathew Wieczorek DSN 8039 and we thank            
them for their many contributions to not only     
the City of St. Louis, but to the world and we    
further direct the Clerk of this Board to spread  
a copy of this Resolution across the minutes      
of these proceedings and to prepare a             
commemorative copy to the end that it may         
be presented to our honoree at a time and         
place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.          
Introduced on the 29th of July, 2011 by:          
Honorable Samuel L. MooreAlderman 4th Ward        
          Resolution No. 156                      
   Police Officer Melissa Chavez                  
                 DSN 7936                         
      WHEREAS, Officer Chavez was                 
nominated for her outstanding work she did        
during the month of March 2011. During the        
month Officer Chavez made a total of 12           
arrests, including the arrest of a convicted      
felon who was found in possesion of a             
concealed firearm relative to an occupied         
vehicle stop. This incident was reported per      
CN: 11-11782; and                                 
     WHEREAS, during the month, Officer           
Chavez had a total of 3 felony charges, 5         
misdemeanor charges and 35 city charges. She      
wrote 18 tickets and 15 parking tags; and         
    WHEREAS, Officer Chavez is always             
aware of crime trends within the district and     
 uses this information to make the Eighth            
 District a safer place for those who live and       
 work in it. She consistantly leads the C Platoon    
 in self initiated activity. For all she did during  
 month of March 2011 and for what she                
 continually does on a daily basis the Eighth        
 District believes she is deserving of the Officer   
 of the Month Award for March 2011.                  
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                            
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of                
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our          
 deliberations to recognize Police Officer           
 Melissa Chavez DSN 7936 and we thank her            
 for her many contributions to not only the          
 City of St. Louis, but to the world and we          
 further direct the Clerk of this Board to spread    
 a copy of this Resolution across the minutes        
 of these proceedings and to prepare a               
 commemorative copy to the end that it may           
 be presented to our honoree at a time and           
 place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.            
 Introduced on the 29th of July, 2011 by:            
 Honorable Samuel L. MooreAlderman 4th Ward          
            Resolution No. 157                       
  Police Officer Michael Schinner                    
           DSN 8803 and                              
  Police Officer Michael Cummings                    
                  DSN 6505                           
      WHEREAS, PO Michael Schinner DSN               
 8803 and PO Michael Cummings DSN 6505               
 work a 20 day work schedule handling over           
 100 radio assignments during this time period.      
 They affected four felony arrests for               
 "Trafficking 2nd" drug charges, two Probation       
 Violations, and two UUW arrests during their        
 tours of duty, with a total of 29 charges; and      
      WHEREAS, they arrested a suspect               
 who was in a high drug area after a computer        
 inquiry found the suspect to have warrants.         
 He was found in possession of a flash light.        
 Inspection of that light by Officers Schinner       
 and Cummings found it to contain a large            
 amount of crack-cocaine; anded                      
      WHEREAS, another arrested suspect              
 was taken into custody after he was seen by         
 PO Schinner disgarding a loaded .22cal              
 handgun; and                                        
       WHEREAS, the Officers arrested                
 another subject after a short foot pursuit in       
 the area of 700 Aubert. This subject had in his     
 possession over 20 pieces of crack-cocaine.         
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                            
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of                
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our          
 deliberations to recognize Police Officer           
 Michael Schinner DSN 8803 and Police                
 Officer Michael Cummings DSN 6505 and               
 we thank them for their many contributions          
 to not only the City of St. Louis, but to the   
 world and we further direct the Clerk of this   
 Board to spread a copy of this Resolution       
 across the minutes of these proceedings and     
 to prepare a commemorative copy to the end      
 that it may be presented to our honoree at a    
 time and place deemed appropriate by the        
 Sponsor.                                        
 Introduced on the 29th of July, 2011 by:        
 Honorable Samuel L. MooreAlderman 4th Ward      
           Resolution No. 158                    
       Police Officer Luke Kallal                
             DSN 7857 and                        
    Police Officer Lindsey Suding                
                    8063                         
      WHEREAS, during the month of May,          
 Officers Kallal and Suding made numerous        
 noteworthy arrests; and                         
      WHEREAS, on 5-2-2011, they                 
 conducted a pedestrian check of a subject who   
 had several warrants. Search incident to arrest 
 revealed him to be in possession of a fully     
 concealed .45 caliber handgun and a large       
 quanity of "Crack Cocaine". Warrants were       
 issued for "UUW" and "VMCSL- Trafficking        
 Drugs"; and                                     
       WHEREAS, on 5-14-2011, they               
 conducted an "Arrest Attempt" at 4431 Evans     
 for a subject who was wanted for an "8th        
 District Robbery." The subject was not          
 present during their attempt to locate him.     
 They quickly built a rapport with the family    
 of the subject and neighbors in the area. They  
 were provided with information that helped      
 lead them to his current location. He was       
 placed under arrest without incident and        
 relinquished to 8th District Detectives; and    
       WHEREAS, their arrests were (8)           
 Felony Charges, (5) Misdemeanor Charges,        
 and (3) Wanted Cards. They had (4) Probation    
 Violations. They recovered two handguns         
 during the month; to include a .45 caliber and  
 a .357 caliber revolver.                        
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                        
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of            
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our      
 deliberations to recognize Police Officer Luke  
 Kallal DSN 7857 and Police Officer Lindsey      
 Suding 8063 and we thank them for their many    
 contributions to not only the City of St. Louis,
 but to the world and we further direct the      
 Clerk of this Board to spread a copy of this    
 Resolution across the minutes of these          
 proceedings and to prepare a commemorative      
 copy to the end that it may be presented to     
 our honoree at a time and place deemed          
 appropriate by the Sponsor.                     
 Introduced on the 29th of July, 2011 by:        
Honorable Samuel L. MooreAlderman 4th Ward         
           Resolution No. 159                      
 Police Officer James Daly DSN 5827                
      WHEREAS, during the month of June,           
Officer Daly made numerous noteworthy              
arrests; and                                       
      WHEREAS, on June 10, 2011 Officer            
Daly conducted a traffic stop after observing      
a vehicle parked in the alley and the occupants    
prowling around the rear yards. The driver of      
the vehicle was found in possession of a loaded    
9mm handgun and the passenger was found in         
possession of heroin. The driver had sixteen       
(16) prior felony convictions. The passenger       
had an active wanted for Parole Violation. A       
warrant was issued by the Circuit Attorney's       
office for the charge of UUW and has since         
been adopted by the US Attorney's office for       
Federal prosecution; and                           
      WHEREAS, Officer Daly also made five         
(5) other narcotics arrests during the month;      
and                                                
      WHEREAS, Officer Daly has a positive         
attitude and a strong work ethic. He is essential  
at helping the younger officers continue to        
develop and fine tune their self initiated         
policing skills.                                   
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                          
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of               
the City of St. Louis that we pause in our         
deliberations to recognize Police Officer James    
Daly DSN 5827 and we thank him for his             
many contributions to not only the City of         
St. Louis, but to the world and we further         
direct the Clerk of this Board to spread a copy    
of this Resolution across the minutes of these     
proceedings and to prepare a commemorative         
copy to the end that it may be presented to        
our honoree at a time and place deemed             
appropriate by the Sponsor.                        
Introduced on the 29th of July, 2011 by:           
Honorable Samuel L. MooreAlderman 4th Ward         
           Resolution No. 160                      
      1961 Vashon High School                      
             50 Year Reunion                       
     WHEREAS, the Vashon High School               
Classes of January and June 1961 are               
celebrating their 50th Class Reunion on August     
19-21, 2011 at the Pear Tree Hotel, St. Louis,     
Missouri; and                                      
      WHEREAS, the graduates are proud of          
their history, heritage, and legacy to the Saint   
Louis Public Schools; and                          
     WHEREAS, some of the graduates have           
received advanced degrees at the Bachelors,        
Masters, and Doctorate levels; and                 
       WHEREAS, the graduates have entered         
 many admirable and honorable professions and      
 fields of endeavor, including, but not limited    
 to education, medicine, social services,          
 business, and private industry; and               
      WHEREAS, some of the graduates have          
 stayed in St. Louis while others have moved       
 to various parts of the United States; and        
      WHEREAS, the graduates have joined           
 with other individuals and produced many          
 children, grandchildren, and great                
 grandchildren; and                                
      WHEREAS, the graduates are happy to          
 be together again for this joyous occasion to     
 celebrate their achievement of graduating from    
 Vashon High School 50 years ago.                  
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                         
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
 deliberations to recognize the 50th year          
 reunion of Vashon High School, Class of 1961      
 and we further direct the Clerk of this Board     
 to spread a copy of this Resolution across the    
 minutes of these proceedings and to prepare a     
 commemorative copy to the end that it may         
 be presented to our honorees at a time and        
 place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.          
 Introduced on the 20th day of August, 2011        
 by:                                               
 Honorable Kacie StarrTriplett,Alderwoman 6thWard  
           Resolution No. 161                      
               Tony Darwish                        
      WHEREAS, in the spring of 2007               
 Community Renewal and Development, Inc.           
 (CRD) and 5th Ward Alderwoman April Ford-         
 Griffin decided that an event to be called the    
 Community Development Carnival was                
 warranted to "Celebrate the History and           
 Revitalization of the 5th Ward"; and              
       WHEREAS, a historic committee was           
 later formed by CRD including membership          
 from North Grand Neighborhood Services,           
 COVAM, CAMCO, Better Family Life, St.             
 Louis Crisis Nursery, World Impact, CHIPS,        
 The Youth and Family Center, Old North St.        
 Louis Restoration Group, Regional Housing         
 and Community Development Alliance and            
 the City of St. Louis; and                        
      WHEREAS, this steering committee has         
 continued to work diligently to provide an        
 experience for 5th Ward residents and             
 stakeholders that includes complimentary          
 rides, games, entertainment, food, school         
 supplies, health screenings and critical service  
 provider information; and                         
     WHEREAS, the implementation of this           
 annual event can only be achieved through the     
 generosity of important community               
 organizations; and                              
       WHEREAS, Crown Food Mart under            
 the leadership of Tony Darwish has stepped      
 forward to establish itself as a major supporter
 of the annual event realizing its importance to 
 5th Ward residents and stakeholders.            
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                       
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of            
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our      
 deliberations to recognize Tony Darwish as a    
 friend and invaluable contributor to the 5th    
 Ward in its continued revitalization and        
 restoration and we further direct the Clerk of  
 this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution  
 across the minutes of these proceedings and     
 to prepare a commemorative copy to the end      
 that it may be presented to our honorees at a   
 time and place deemed appropriate by the        
 Sponsor.                                        
 Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011      
 by:                                             
 HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward

 (CRD) and 5th Ward Alderwoman April Ford-       
 Griffin decided that an event to be called the  
 Community Development Carnival was              
 warranted to "Celebrate the History and         
 Revitalization of the 5th Ward"; and

 later formed by CRD including membership        
 from North Grand Neighborhood Services,         
 COVAM, CAMCO, Better Family Life, St.           
 Louis Crisis Nursery, World Impact, CHIPS,      
 The Youth and Family Center, Old North St.      
 Louis Restoration Group, Regional Housing       
 and Community Development Alliance and          
 the City of St. Louis; and                      
      WHEREAS, this steering committee has       
 continued to work diligently to provide an      
 experience for 5th Ward residents and           
 stakeholders that includes complimentary        
 rides, games, entertainment, food, school       
 supplies, health screenings and critical service
 provider information; and                       
      WHEREAS, the implementation of this        
 annual event can only be achieved through the   
 generosity of important community               
 organizations; and                              
      WHEREAS, McCormack Baron Salazar           
 under the leadership of Vince Bennett has       
 stepped forward to establish itself as a major  
 supporter of the annual event realizing its     
 importance to 5th Ward residents and            
 stakeholders.                                   
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT

the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
deliberations to recognize Vince Bennett as a

restoration and we further direct the Clerk of    
this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution    
across the minutes of these proceedings and       
to prepare a commemorative copy to the end        
that it may be presented to our honorees at a     
time and place deemed appropriate by the          
Sponsor.

supplies, health screenings and critical service  
provider information; and

organizations; and

 supplies, health screenings and critical service
 provider information; and

 supplies, health screenings and critical service  
 provider information; and

 provider information; and

and Community Development Alliance and

continued to work diligently to provide an        
experience for 5th Ward residents and             
stakeholders that includes complimentary          
rides, games, entertainment, food, school         
supplies, health screenings and critical service  
provider information; and

annual event can only be achieved through the     
generosity of important community                 
organizations; and

the leadership of Gary Bess has stepped           
forward to establish itself as a major supporter  
of the annual event realizing its importance to   
5th Ward residents and stakeholders.

 restoration and we further direct the Clerk of

 to prepare a commemorative copy to the end        
 that it may be presented to our honorees at a     
 time and place deemed appropriate by the          
 Sponsor.
