 Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011      
 by:                                             
 HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward 
           Resolution No. 172                    
               Brian McKee                       
      WHEREAS, in the spring of 2007             
 Community Renewal and Development, Inc.         
 (CRD) and 5th Ward Alderwoman April Ford-       
 Griffin decided that an event to be called the  
 Community Development Carnival was              
 warranted to "Celebrate the History and         
 Revitalization of the 5th Ward"; and            
       WHEREAS, a historic committee was         
 later formed by CRD including membership        
 from North Grand Neighborhood Services,         
 COVAM, CAMCO, Better Family Life, St.           
 Louis Crisis Nursery, World Impact, CHIPS,      
 The Youth and Family Center, Old North St.      
 Louis Restoration Group, Regional Housing       
 and Community Development Alliance and          
 the City of St. Louis; and                      
      WHEREAS, this steering committee has       
 continued to work diligently to provide an      
 experience for 5th Ward residents and           
 stakeholders that includes complimentary        
 rides, games, entertainment, food, school       
 supplies, health screenings and critical service
 provider information; and                       
      WHEREAS, the implementation of this        
 annual event can only be achieved through the   
 generosity of important community               
 organizations; and                              
      WHEREAS, McKee Construction                
 under the leadership of Brian McKee has         
 stepped forward to establish itself as a major  
 supporter of the annual event realizing its     
 importance to 5th Ward residents and            
 stakeholders.                                   
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                       
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of            
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our      
 deliberations to recognize Brian McKee as a     
 friend and invaluable contributor to the 5th    
 Ward in its continued revitalization and        
 restoration and we further direct the Clerk of  
 this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution  
 across the minutes of these proceedings and     
 to prepare a commemorative copy to the end      
 that it may be presented to our honorees at a   
 time and place deemed appropriate by the        
 Sponsor.                                        
 Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011      
by:                                               
HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward   
          Resolution No. 173                      
             Gloria Gooden                        
     WHEREAS, in the spring of 2007               
Community Renewal and Development, Inc.           
(CRD) and 5th Ward Alderwoman April Ford-         
Griffin decided that an event to be called the    
Community Development Carnival was                
warranted to "Celebrate the History and           
Revitalization of the 5th Ward"; and              
      WHEREAS, a historic committee was           
later formed by CRD including membership          
from North Grand Neighborhood Services,           
COVAM, CAMCO, Better Family Life, St.             
Louis Crisis Nursery, World Impact, CHIPS,        
The Youth and Family Center, Old North St.        
Louis Restoration Group, Regional Housing         
and Community Development Alliance and            
the City of St. Louis; and                        
     WHEREAS, this steering committee has         
continued to work diligently to provide an        
experience for 5th Ward residents and             
stakeholders that includes complimentary          
rides, games, entertainment, food, school         
supplies, health screenings and critical service  
provider information; and                         
     WHEREAS, the implementation of this          
annual event can only be achieved through the     
generosity of important community                 
organizations; and                                
      WHEREAS, Gooden and Daughter                
Plumbing under the leadership of Gloria           
Gooden has stepped forward to establish itself    
as a major supporter of the annual event          
realizing its importance to 5th Ward residents    
and stakeholders.                                 
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                         
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
deliberations to recognize Gloria Gooden as a     
friend and invaluable contributor to the 5th      
Ward in its continued revitalization and          
restoration and we further direct the Clerk of    
this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution    
across the minutes of these proceedings and       
to prepare a commemorative copy to the end        
that it may be presented to our honorees at a     
time and place deemed appropriate by the          
Sponsor.                                          
Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011        
by:                                               
HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward   
          Resolution No. 174                      
           Ted Thorton                            
   WHEREAS, in the spring of 2007                 
Community Renewal and Development, Inc.           
 (CRD) and 5th Ward Alderwoman April Ford-         
 Griffin decided that an event to be called the    
 Community Development Carnival was                
 warranted to "Celebrate the History and           
 Revitalization of the 5th Ward"; and              
       WHEREAS, a historic committee was           
 later formed by CRD including membership          
 from North Grand Neighborhood Services,           
 COVAM, CAMCO, Better Family Life, St.             
 Louis Crisis Nursery, World Impact, CHIPS,        
 The Youth and Family Center, Old North St.        
 Louis Restoration Group, Regional Housing         
 and Community Development Alliance and            
 the City of St. Louis; and                        
      WHEREAS, this steering committee has         
 continued to work diligently to provide an        
 experience for 5th Ward residents and             
 stakeholders that includes complimentary          
 rides, games, entertainment, food, school         
 supplies, health screenings and critical service  
 provider information; and                         
      WHEREAS, the implementation of this          
 annual event can only be achieved through the     
 generosity of important community                 
 organizations; and                                
       WHEREAS, Imperial Palace under the          
 leadership of Ted Thorton has stepped forward     
 to establish itself as a major supporter of the   
 annual event realizing its importance to 5th      
 Ward residents and stakeholders.                  
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                         
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
 deliberations to recognize Ted Thorton as a       
 friend and invaluable contributor to the 5th      
 Ward in its continued revitalization and          
 restoration and we further direct the Clerk of    
 this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution    
 across the minutes of these proceedings and       
 to prepare a commemorative copy to the end        
 that it may be presented to our honorees at a     
 time and place deemed appropriate by the          
 Sponsor.                                          
 Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011        
 by:                                               
 HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward   
           Resolution No. 175                      
              Jimmi Darwish                        
      WHEREAS, in the spring of 2007               
 Community Renewal and Development, Inc.           
 (CRD) and 5th Ward Alderwoman April Ford-         
 Griffin decided that an event to be called the    
 Community Development Carnival was                
 warranted to "Celebrate the History and           
 Revitalization of the 5th Ward"; and              
       WHEREAS, a historic committee was           
 later formed by CRD including membership          
 from North Grand Neighborhood Services,           
 COVAM, CAMCO, Better Family Life, St.           
 Louis Crisis Nursery, World Impact, CHIPS,      
 The Youth and Family Center, Old North St.      
 Louis Restoration Group, Regional Housing       
 and Community Development Alliance and          
 the City of St. Louis; and                      
      WHEREAS, this steering committee has       
 continued to work diligently to provide an      
 experience for 5th Ward residents and           
 stakeholders that includes complimentary        
 rides, games, entertainment, food, school       
 supplies, health screenings and critical service
 provider information; and                       
      WHEREAS, the implementation of this        
 annual event can only be achieved through the   
 generosity of important community               
 organizations; and                              
      WHEREAS, Mobil Gas Companies               
 under the leadership of Jimmi Darwish has       
 stepped forward to establish itself as a major  
 supporter of the annual event realizing its     
 importance to 5th Ward residents and            
 stakeholders.                                   
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                       
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of            
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our      
 deliberations to recognize Jimmi Darwish as a   
 friend and invaluable contributor to the 5th    
 Ward in its continued revitalization and        
 restoration and we further direct the Clerk of  
 this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution  
 across the minutes of these proceedings and     
 to prepare a commemorative copy to the end      
 that it may be presented to our honorees at a   
 time and place deemed appropriate by the        
 Sponsor.                                        
 Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011      
 by:                                             
 HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward 
           Resolution No. 176                    
              Joann Williams                     
      WHEREAS, in the spring of 2007             
 Community Renewal and Development, Inc.         
 (CRD) and 5th Ward Alderwoman April Ford-       
 Griffin decided that an event to be called the  
 Community Development Carnival was              
 warranted to "Celebrate the History and         
 Revitalization of the 5th Ward"; and            
       WHEREAS, a historic committee was         
 later formed by CRD including membership        
 from North Grand Neighborhood Services,         
 COVAM, CAMCO, Better Family Life, St.           
 Louis Crisis Nursery, World Impact, CHIPS,      
 The Youth and Family Center, Old North St.      
 Louis Restoration Group, Regional Housing       
 and Community Development Alliance and          
 the City of St. Louis; and                      
      WHEREAS, this steering committee has       
continued to work diligently to provide an        
experience for 5th Ward residents and             
stakeholders that includes complimentary          
rides, games, entertainment, food, school         
supplies, health screenings and critical service  
provider information; and                         
     WHEREAS, the implementation of this          
annual event can only be achieved through the     
generosity of important community                 
organizations; and                                
      WHEREAS, STL Carpenter's District           
Council under the leadership of Joann Williams    
has stepped forward to establish itself as a      
major supporter of the annual event realizing     
its importance to 5th Ward residents and          
stakeholders.                                     
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                         
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
deliberations to recognize Joann Williams as a    
friend and invaluable contributor to the 5th      
Ward in its continued revitalization and          
restoration and we further direct the Clerk of    
this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution    
across the minutes of these proceedings and       
to prepare a commemorative copy to the end        
that it may be presented to our honorees at a     
time and place deemed appropriate by the          
Sponsor.                                          
Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011        
by:                                               
HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward   
          Resolution No. 177                      
        Rigazzi's Restaurant                      
    WHEREAS, Rigazzi's Restaurant is the          
oldest restaurant in the historic "Hill"          
Neighborhood; and                                 
     WHEREAS, Rigazzi's opened in 1957            
on 4945 Daggett Avenue by Louis and               
Josephine Aiazzi; and                             
     WHEREAS, Rigazzi's continues to be           
operated by Josephine, with her son Mark,         
(Restaurateur of the year 2010) and his wife,     
Joan; and                                         
      WHEREAS, we name this street                
Rigazzi's Place in honor of their commitment      
to the City of St. Louis by providing unrivaled   
hospitality with over 200 menu items and the      
world-renowned "Frozen Fish Bowl" and the         
values of Pride and Family - so dear to the       
"Hill" Neighborhood.                              
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                         
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
deliberations to recognize Rigazzi's              
Restaurant and we further direct the Clerk of     
this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution    
 across the minutes of these proceedings and       
 to prepare a commemorative copy to the end        
 that it may be presented to our honorees at a     
 time and place deemed appropriate by the          
 Sponsor.                                          
 Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011        
 by:                                               
 Honorable Joseph Vollmer,Alderman 10th Ward       
           Resolution No. 178                      
         Shirley Bradley LeFlore                   
       WHEREAS, Shirley Bradley LeFlore is         
 a published and oral poet/performing artist       
 formerly an adjunct professor of women and        
 ethnic literature at the University of Missouri,  
 St. Louis. Currently, adjunct professor at        
 Lindenwood University, teaching in the            
 creative writing cluster; and                     
       WHEREAS, Shirley Bradley LeFlore            
 also taught at such institutions as Harris-Stowe  
 and Montclair State University in New Jersey      
 and been an artist-in-residence at various        
 colleges and universities throughout the          
 country; and                                      
       WHEREAS, Shirley Bradley LeFlore            
 has been referred to as poet/professor            
 extraordinaire, having wrote projects that were   
 artistically driven, but also centered on key     
 social issues such as projects created and        
 produced stage productions " Behavior As          
 Theater for adolescents" and "Deliverance",a      
 play that was among one of the first regional     
 productions centered around AIDS and HIV;         
 and                                               
       WHEREAS, Shirley Bradley LeFlore            
 Often referred to as "Poet LeFlore", during       
 the nineties, she lived in the New Jersey and     
 New York area where she performed her             
 original poetry extensively on the academic,      
 social/cultural arts, political, religious, and   
 media (TV & Radio) circuit. She is one of few     
 poets with a vast background in collaborative/    
 staged poetry with musicians, dancers, visual     
 arts, including film as part of the reknown       
 historical BAG (Black Artist Group of St.         
 Louis). At the start of her career, LeFlore,      
 was one of the first artist/writers in the        
 Missouri school districts to create a project     
 working with teachers and students K-12           
 grades conducting writing labs and creative       
 writing workshops. This eventually                
 catapulted her to take the program in various     
 schools around the country; and                   
       WHEREAS, Shirley Bradley LeFlore As         
 a solo spoken word artist she has blended the     
 vocal texture of her poetry with the music        
 giants of jazz, blues, gospel/spirituals and      
 classical music. This includes: The World Jazz    
 Saxophone Quartet; Woodwind virtuoso JD           
 Parran, whom she created the duo Word and         
 Wind with, also working with Parran's NYC           
 based music group Spirit Stage; and Hammiet         
 Bluiet's BBQ Band recordings. LeFlore's             
 writings have been performed on stage. Most         
 noted are: "Songs Of River Magic" at the            
 Kennedy Center in Washington, DC; and her           
 critically acclaimed original spoken word           
 composition in which she performed at               
 historical Weil Hall at Carnegie Hall in New        
 York; and                                           
       WHEREAS, the New Jersey Journal               
 refers to Shirley Bradley LeFlore as "Poet          
 Natural". Her poetry and writings have              
 appeared in several anthologies, magazines,         
 and newsprint, including a multi-ethnic/            
 cultural arts 4 part series for QTV, Queens,        
 NY. She has been the major poet presenting          
 the works of literary/poetry legends,               
 Gwendolyn Brooks and Margaret Walker. Her           
 poetry is featured prominently in the critically    
 acclaimed 2009 Random House/Broadway                
 Books novel, "Wildflowers", written by her          
 daughter, and National Bestselling Author,          
 Lyah Beth LeFlore; and                              
       WHEREAS, Shirley Bradley LeFlore              
 holds a BA in Language Arts and Behavioral          
 Science from Webster University in St. Louis,       
 Missouri, and an MA in Psychology from              
 Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri.       
 She was also a National Institute in Minority       
 Mental Health Fellow (NIMH). Additionally,          
 LeFlore has an extensive background in              
 administration and instruction in higher            
 education. Her teachings and workshops              
 include both student and teacher workshops          
 in creative writing.                                
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                            
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of                
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our          
 deliberations to congratulate Shirley Bradley       
 LeFlore for extensive years of service with         
 the St. Louis Public Schools and universities       
 and for her outstanding contribution to             
 education. We wish her peace and happiness          
 in her outstanding career and we direct the         
 Clerk of this Board to spread a copy of this        
 Resolution and to further prepare a                 
 commemorative copy to the end that it may           
 be presented to our honoree at The Missouri         
 History Museum.                                     
 Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011          
 by:                                                 
 Honorable Lewis E. Reed, President, Board ofAldermen
            Resolution No. 179                       
  Dedication of the Freeman R. Bosley                
 Jr. Residence Hall and Dining Facility              
     WHEREAS, Freeman R. Bosley, Jr.                 
 became the forty-seventh and the first African-     
 American Mayor of the City of St. Louis on          
April 6, 1993 and served his four year term           
until 1997; and                                       
      WHEREAS, Mr. Bosley is now an                   
attorney with Bosley and Associates, LLC              
with two locations in the St. Louis area; and         
      WHEREAS, during Mr. Bosley's tenure             
as Mayor the City of St. Louis sold 18 acres          
of prime land to Harris Stowe State                   
University for ten dollars, which was crucial         
for the extraordinary mission enhancement             
and campus expansion for this historic                
institution; and                                      
     WHEREAS, in 1993, this institution               
was authorized by the Legislature of the State        
of Missouri to expand its mission to include          
the preparation of professionals - at the             
baccalaureate degree level - in selected applied      
disciplines, including teacher education,             
thereby responding to the identified higher           
education needs of the Metropolitan St. Louis         
Region. This college, under a mandate by              
Governor Blunt and the Missouri State                 
Legislature, was declared to be a full-fledged        
university with the rights, privileges, and           
responsibilities thereunto related; and               
      WHEREAS, in 2005, the university                
expanded its campus an established it's first         
satellite campus in near-south St. Louis, and         
housed the Busch School of Business                   
Administration. In 2006, the university               
became a residential campus with the                  
dedication of the Rev. William G. Gillespie           
Residence Hall and Student Center; and                
      WHEREAS, on Friday, August 12,                  
2011, Harris-Stowe State University will              
dedicate it's newest and second residential           
facility, The Freeman R. Bosley, Jr. Residence        
Hall and Dining Facility.                             
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                             
RESOLVED by this Board of Aldermen, that              
we join Harris-Stowe State University in the          
proud and joyous celebration of this event,           
and wish to offer former Mayor Freeman                
Bosley, Jr. our congratulations and best wishes       
on the dedication of this facility and we further     
direct the Clerk of this Board to spread a copy       
of this Resolution across the minutes of these        
proceedings and to prepare a commemorative            
copy to the end that it may be presented to           
our honoree at a time and place deemed                
appropriate by the Sponsor.                           
Introduced on the 12th day of August, 2011            
by:                                                   
Honorable Freeman Bosley, Sr.,Alderman 3rd Ward       
Honorable Lewis E. Reed, President, Board ofAldermen  
Honorable Charles QuincyTroupe,Alderman 1stWard       
Honorable Dionne Flowers,Alderwoman 2nd Ward          
Honorable Samuel L. Moore,Alderman 4th Ward           
 HonorableApril Ford Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward   
 Honorable Kacie StarrTriplett,Alderwoman 6thWard  
 Honorable Phyllis Young,Alderwoman 7th Ward       
 Honorable Stephen Conway,Alderman 8th Ward        
 Honorable Kenneth Ortmann,Alderman 9thWard        
 Honorable Joseph Vollmer,Alderman 10th Ward       
 Honorable ThomasAlbert Villa,Alderman 11th Ward   
 Honorable LarryArnowitz,Alderman 12th Ward        
 HonorableAlfred Wessels, Jr.,Alderman 13th Ward   
 Honorable Carol Howard,Alderwoman 14th Ward       
 Honorable Jennifer Florida,Alderwoman 15th Ward   
 Honorable Donna Baringer,Alderwoman 16th Ward     
 Honorable Joseph Roddy,Alderman 17th Ward         
 HonorableTerry Kennedy,Alderman 18th Ward         
 Honorable Marlene E. Davis,Alderwoman 19th Ward   
 Honorable Craig Schmid,Alderman 20th Ward         
 HonorableAntonio D. French,Alderman 21st Ward     
 Honorable Jeffrey L. Boyd,Alderman 22nd Ward      
 Honorable Joe Vaccaro,Alderman 23rd Ward          
 Honorable Scott Ogilvie,Alderman 24th Ward        
 Honorable Shane Cohn,Alderman 25th Ward           
 Honorable Frank Williamson,Alderman 26th Ward     
 Honorable Gregory J. Carter,Alderman 27th Ward    
 Honorable Lyda Krewson,Alderwoman 28th Ward       
           Resolution No. 180                      
              Marion Hudson                        
      WHEREAS, we pause in our                     
 deliberations to note the passing of Marion       
 Hudson on August 7, 2011; and                     
      WHEREAS, Marion Hudson was born              
 February 3, 1932 in Stello, Mississippi. He       
 was one of ten children born to William (Boss)    
 Hudson and Anna Hudson Covington; and             
      WHEREAS, Marion was baptized and             
 served on the deacon board in Gary, Indiana.      
 The Hudson family moved to St. Louis and          
 Marion attended SLPS (Simmons Elementary          
 and Washington Tech). In 1954 he was              
 inducted into the United States Air Force as a    
 private. He received the National Defense         
 Service Medal and an honorable discharge from     
 service in 1960; and                              
       WHEREAS, Marion resided in Gary,            
 Indiana after his discharge, and was employed     
 as a certified welder for the United Steel        
 Company. He moved back to St. Louis to            
 care for his mother and two children. Later,      
 he was united in holy matrimony to Beatrice       
 Thomas for thirty four years on this day of       
 August 12th. With this union they become a        
 family of seven; and                              
       WHEREAS, he worked at the American          
 Car Foundry. Later he retired and worked          
 part-time for the SLPS transportation and then    
 BJC shuttle service; and                          
       WHEREAS, Marion was a very wise,            
 strong and independent man. He was a man          
 that believed in respect from the young and       
 old. He was affectionately known as "Papa         
 and Poppy". His passion was to always          
 educate himself and his grandchildren with     
 past history and current events he watched     
 many old western movies and loved watching     
 the game of golf (T. Woods fan). Most of the   
 time he was a very serious man but allowed     
 an unexpected witty comment or joke to spill   
 over. He enjoyed family visits, which were     
 often, but was known to say, as he stood at    
 the front door with it open. "The kitchen is   
 closed and it's time to get out!"; and         
      WHEREAS, he leaves to cherish his         
 memory a loving wife, Mrs. Beatrice Hudson;    
 four daughters: Angela Newton (Robert).        
 Bernadine Jenkins (Derrick), Mary Thomas,      
 and Donna Thomas (Gregory); three sons:        
 Ralph Herron, Ajuma Muhammad (Drena),          
 Daniel Thomas (Karen) and many                 
 grandchildren and a host of nieces, nephews,   
 cousins and friends.                           
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                      
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of           
 the City of St. Louis that we pause to         
 remember the many accomplishments and          
 contributions of Marion Hudson and we join     
 with his many friends in expressing our sorrow 
 at his passing, and we further direct the Clerk
 of this Board to spread a copy of this         
 Resolution across the minutes of these         
 proceedings and to prepare a memorial copy     
 for presentation to the Hudson family, at a    
 time and place deemed appropriate by the       
 Sponsor.                                       
 Introduced on the 12th day of July, 2011 by:   
 Honorable Freeman Bosley, Sr.,Alderman 3rd Ward
           Resolution No. 181                   
     Dr. Mary Anne Tuggle Tillman               
      WHEREAS, we have been apprised of         
 the retirement of longtime St. Louis           
 pediatrician, Dr. Mary Anne Tuggle Tillman;    
 and                                            
      WHEREAS, Dr. Tillman was born             
 September 4, 1935 in Bristow, Oklahoma to      
 Thomas and Ruthie Tuggle. She married Judge    
 Daniel Tillman on April 20, 1957; and          
      WHEREAS, she fulfilled her mother's       
 wish by receiving her medical degree at        
 Howard University in Washington, D.C., and     
 completing her internship and residency at     
 Homer G. Phillips Hospital in St. Louis.       
 Throughout her career, Dr. Tillman worked to   
 improve the lives of children by devoting      
 herself to community causes; and               
       WHEREAS, Dr. Tillman estimates that      
 she's cared for about 200,000 patients over    
 the years, and in many cases that number       
 includes families bringing four generations of 
 their children to her for care. She refers to  
them as her extended family and calls them       
her children, grandchildren and great-           
grandchildren; and                               
     WHEREAS, Dr. Tillman has served on          
the board of directors for the Annie Malone      
Children & Family Service Center since 1976,     
and she has worked with the March of Dimes       
National Foundation in the area of adolescent    
pregnancy. She served six years on the National  
Committee on Adoptions and Dependent             
Care for the American Academy of Pediatrics.     
A feature story on Dr. Tillman appeared in       
Good Housekeeping magazine, and she              
received distinguished service awards from       
Howard University, the St. Louis Globe-          
Democrat and the National Medical                
Association; and                                 
     WHEREAS, despite all of her                 
professional accomplishments, Dr. Tillman        
considers her family as her greatest             
achievement. She and her husband, retired        
circuit court judge Daniel Tillman, have two     
children: their daughter, Dana, an electrical    
engineer, and their son Daniel Jr., an           
anesthesiologist. The Tillmans also have a       
granddaughter who holds a master's degree in     
public health, a grandson in his third year of   
college, and a granddaughter entering            
kindergarten this fall.                          
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                        
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of             
the City of Saint Louis that we pause in our     
deliberations to congratulate and recognize the  
retirement of Dr. Mary Anne Tuggle Tillman       
and thank her for her many contributions to      
the City of Saint Louis and we further direct    
the Clerk of this Board to spread a copy of      
this Resolution across the minutes of these      
proceedings and to prepare a commemorative       
copy to the end that it may be presented to      
our honoree at a time and place deemed           
appropriate by the Sponsor.                      
Introduced on the 19th day of August, 2011       
by:                                              
Honorable Lyda Krewson,Alderwoman 28th Ward      
          Resolution No. 182                     
        Peter Martin Baricevich                  
      WHEREAS, we have been apprised that        
after almost 22 years of dedicated service to    
the City of St. Louis, Peter Martin Baricevich   
will retire on September 1, 2011; and            
     WHEREAS, Pete began his career with         
the Building Division on October 9, 1989 as a    
Building Inspector I; and                        
      WHEREAS, Pete worked in Fire Safety        
for nine years; and                              
    WHEREAS, in May 1993, Pete was               
promoted to the position of Building Inspector   
 II; and                                           
      WHEREAS, Pete was promoted to                
 Building Inspector Supervisor I in 1999; and      
     WHEREAS, Pete will be rehabbing a             
 newer, older house in retirement; and             
       WHEREAS, Pete will be sorely missed         
 by his co-workers, mangers, elected officials,    
 citizens and the Deputy Building                  
 Commissioner who have all had the benefit of      
 experiencing Pete's code knowledge, friendly      
 customer service mentality and his positive       
 attitude. These aforementioned skills have        
 made Pete one of the best supervisors the         
 Building Division has ever had.                   
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                         
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of              
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our        
 deliberations to congratulate Peter Martin        
 Baricevich for almost 22 years of service with    
 the Building Division of the City of St. Louis    
 and we wish him peace and happiness in his        
 retirement and we direct the Clerk of this Board  
 to spread a copy of this Resolution across the    
 minutes of these proceedings and to further       
 prepare a commemorative copy to the end           
 that it may be presented to our honoree at a      
 time and place deemed appropriate by the          
 Sponsor.                                          
 Introduced on the 19th day of August, 2011        
 by:                                               
 HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward   
 Honorable Marlene E. Davis,Alderwoman 19th Ward   
           Resolution No. 183                      
              Cylesta Porter                       
      WHEREAS, we have been apprised that          
 on August 20, 2011, Cylesta Porter will           
 celebrate her glorious 97th Birthday; and         
      WHEREAS, Cylesta Porter was born             
 and raised in Oakland, Mississippi; and           
      WHEREAS, many years later, Cylesta           
 met and married her husband Robert Earl in        
 Holy Matrimony, to this marriage three            
 children were born, Portia, Robert Earl and       
 John.     Mrs. Porter also has three              
 grandchildren; and                                
      WHEREAS, in addition to her many             
 responsibilities as wife and mother, Cylesta      
 has been an active and committed follower of      
 Jesus Christ and a faithful member of Mt.         
 Olive Missionary Baptist church, having           
 joined in 1941; and                               
      WHEREAS, she loves and enjoys                
 helping young adults become strong young          
 Christian Followers of Christ, as she was         
 brought up to be; and                             
      WHEREAS, during her long and                 
 productive life, Cylesta has demonstrated in   
 countless ways her dedication to the welfare   
 of others and has earned the respect and       
 affection of people from all walks of life; and
      WHEREAS, Cylesta was a seamstress         
 and has sewed for many of the ladies at the    
 church and she was also a member of the        
 Health Unit and Mothers Board; and             
      WHEREAS, on August 20, 2011 her           
 family will celebrate her birthday, to God be  
 the Glory for the things she has done.         
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                       
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of           
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our     
 deliberations to congratulate Cylesta Porter   
 on the occasion of her 97th Birthday and we    
 wish her continued peace, good health and      
 happiness and we further direct the Clerk of   
 this Board to spread a copy of this Resolution 
 across the minutes of these proceedings and    
 to prepare a commemorative copy to the end     
 that it may be presented to our honoree at a   
 time and place deemed appropriate by the       
 Sponsor.                                       
 Introduced on the 19th day of August, 2011     
 by:                                            
 HonorableApril Ford Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward
           Resolution No. 184                   
    Thomas and Kathleen Bailey                  
      WHEREAS, The Missouri Black               
 Exposition was founded by Thomas and           
 Kathleen Bailey in 1992; and                   
      WHEREAS, for 20 years the Missouri        
 Black Expo has been an intricate part of the   
 Missouri community and has provided            
 attendees exposure to outstanding resources    
 such as health information, critical analysis  
 from home ownership to small business loans    
 from cooking instruction to future boxing      
 champions; and                                 
      WHEREAS, Thomas and Kathleen              
 Bailey have structured the Missouri Black      
 Expo to be on the cutting edge of creating a   
 family-oriented environment, which focuses     
 on the promotion of youth development,         
 mental health and family bonding; and          
      WHEREAS, Thomas and Kathleen              
 Bailey, through the Missouri Black Expo, have  
 been committed to providing an overall diverse 
 experience of programs and projects which      
 affect the entire community; and               
      WHEREAS, under the leadership of          
 Thomas and Kathleen Bailey (better known       
 as Tom and Kaye) the Missouri Black Expo       
 has symbolically laid the foundation for       
 economic growth by providing the business      
 community with an environment in which to      
display their goods and services; and                 
     WHEREAS, Tom, as President, and                  
Kaye, as Operations Director, have guided             
the Missouri Black Expo to become the largest         
empowerment event in the state of Missouri            
and an excellent way for the business                 
community to expose themselves to the general         
population; and                                       
     WHEREAS, the Bailey Family is                    
committed to serving the community through            
volunteerism as members of organizations              
such as 100 Black Men of St. Louis since              
1991; and                                             
      WHEREAS, the Bailey Family founded              
the Annual Prostate Cancer Survivor's &               
Awareness Walk, which is a project to raise           
awareness of prostate cancer and to help find         
a cure; and                                           
      WHEREAS, the Bailey Family co-                  
founded in association with Bryant-Morrow             
Enterprises and 100 Black Men, an                     
entertainment company titled 100                      
Entertainment International which provided            
talent booking and event services to the 106          
Chapters of 100 Black Men of America and              
also owner of Bailey Promotions marketing a           
talent booking, event development, and                
production company.                                   
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                             
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen for                 
the City of St. Louis that we pause in our            
deliberations to recognize the contributions          
and selflessness of Tom and Kaye Bailey and           
direct the Clerk of this Board to prepare a           
commemorative copy of this resolution to the          
end that it may be presented to our honorees          
at a time and place deemed appropriate by             
the sponsor.                                          
Introduced on the 19th day of August, 2011            
by:                                                   
Honorable Terry Kennedy,Alderman 18th Ward            
Honorable Lewis E. Reed, President, Board ofAldermen  
Honorable Charles QuincyTroupe,Alderman 1stWard       
Honorable Dionne Flowers,Alderwoman 2nd Ward          
Honorable Freeman Bosley, Sr.,Alderman 3rd Ward       
Honorable Samuel L. Moore,Alderman 4th Ward           
HonorableApril Ford Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward       
Honorable Kacie StarrTriplett,Alderwoman 6thWard      
Honorable Marlene E. Davis,Alderwoman 19th Ward       
HonorableAntonio D. French,Alderman 21st Ward         
Honorable Jeffrey L. Boyd,Alderman 22nd Ward          
Honorable Frank Williamson,Alderman 26th Ward         
Honorable Gregory J. Carter,Alderman 27th Ward        
           Resolution No. 185                         
           Yolanda Adams                              
     WHEREAS, Singer and Songwriter,                  
Yolanda Adams and her Health & Lifestyle              
Tour is developing continued awareness of             
 major chronic illnesses that adversely affect         
 African Americans, such as diabetes, heart            
 disease and high blood pressure, also known           
 as hypertension, a serious chronic condition          
 which affects approximately 1 in 3 adults in          
 the United States; and                                
      WHEREAS, African Americans are at a              
 higher risk of developing high blood pressure         
 than other ethnic group for reasons that are          
 not fully understood; and                             
       WHEREAS, the Believe in Healthy BP,             
 a national hypertension awareness campaign            
 has been launched by Novartis                         
 Pharmaceuticals Corporation in conjunction            
 with the 2011 Yolanda Adams Health &                  
 Lifestyle Tour; and                                   
       WHEREAS, The Believe in Healthy BP              
 hypertension awareness campaign has a                 
 mission to: raise awareness of the dangers of         
 high blood pressure within the African                
 American population; communicate the need             
 for regular blood pressure screenings; issue a        
 call to action for people to get their blood          
 pressure checked; encourage those affected by         
 high blood pressure to work closely with their        
 healthcare professionals to manage their blood        
 pressure, and seek effective medications, if          
 necessary; and actively incorporate lifestyle         
 changes and modifications; and                        
      WHEREAS, the City of St. Louis                   
 supports the mission of the Believe in Healthy        
 BP hypertension awareness campaign.                   
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                             
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen for                 
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our            
 deliberations to recognize the contributions          
 and selflessness of Yolanda Adams and direct          
 the Clerk of this Board to prepare a                  
 commemorative copy of this resolution to the          
 end that it may be presented to our honorees          
 at a time and place deemed appropriate by             
 the sponsor.                                          
 Introduced on the 19th day of August, 2011            
 by:                                                   
 HonorableTerry Kennedy,Alderman 18th Ward             
 Honorable Lewis E. Reed, President, Board ofAldermen  
 Honorable Charles QuincyTroupe,Alderman 1stWard       
 Honorable Dionne Flowers,Alderwoman 2nd Ward          
 Honorable Freeman Bosley, Sr.,Alderman 3rd Ward       
 Honorable Samuel L. Moore,Alderman 4th Ward           
 HonorableApril Ford Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward       
 Honorable Kacie StarrTriplett,Alderwoman 6thWard      
 Honorable Marlene E. Davis,Alderwoman 19th Ward       
 HonorableAntonio D. French,Alderman 21st Ward         
 Honorable Jeffrey L. Boyd,Alderman 22nd Ward          
 Honorable Frank Williamson,Alderman 26th Ward         
 Honorable Gregory J. Carter,Alderman 27th Ward        
            Resolution No. 186                       
 2011 St. Peter Claver Day Celebration               
       WHEREAS, Saint Peter Claver was               
 born in Catalonia in Spain in 1581 and is often     
 known as the Apostle of the Negro Slaves;           
 and                                                 
       WHEREAS, Saint Peter Claver aided             
 enslaved people by bringing food, caring for        
 the sick and ministering to their souls. Over a     
 forty year period, Peter baptized over three        
 hundred thousand enslaved people; and               
      WHEREAS, Peter throughout his life             
 made frequent visits to hospitals and prisons       
 and spent many hours of each day hearing            
 confessions and preaching in public squares;        
 and                                                 
      WHEREAS, Saint Peter Claver died on            
 September 8, 1654 and was beatified by Pope         
 Pius IX in 1851. He is remembered and               
 honored on September 11th.                          
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                           
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of                
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our          
 deliberations to recognize the selflessness         
 labors of Saint Peter Claver and acknowledge        
 the 2011 St. Peter Claver Day Celebration           
 and we further direct the Clerk of this Board       
 to spread a copy of this Resolution across the      
 minutes of these proceedings and to prepare a       
 commemorative copy to the end that it may           
 be presented to our honoree at a time and           
 place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.            
 Introduced on the 26th day of August, 2011          
 by:                                                 
 HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward     
 Honorable Lewis E. Reed, President, Board ofAldermen
            Resolution No. 187                       
           Mary Louise Swims                         
      WHEREAS, we pause in our                       
 deliberations to note the passing of longtime       
 St. Louis resident, Mary Louise Swims; and          
       WHEREAS, Mary Louise Swims was                
 born on September 21, 1931 in Carrollton,           
 Mississippi to Percy and Fannie Bell                
 Robinson. At an early age, Mary                     
 demonstrated a love for cooking and would           
 often shoulder the responsibility of cooking        
 for family gatherings, as well as sharing food      
 with neighbors and friends in need; and             
       WHEREAS, Mary united in Holy                  
 Matrimony with L.B. Swims on January 5,             
 1952 and to this union six children was born,       
 three daughters and three sons. They moved          
 to St. Louis, Missouri in the mid 1950's.           
 Mary worked as a head cook in various               
 restaurants, as well as opening her own             
 restaurant, Mary's Cafe; and                        
     WHEREAS, she confessed a hope in            
Christ at Pleasant Grove M.B. Church in          
Carrollton, Mississippi. Mary later joined       
Original Friendship M.B. Church under the        
leadership of Reverend C.V. Smith and            
continued to serve faithfully under the          
leadership of Reverend A.M. Smith until her      
health began to fail; and                        
      WHEREAS, Mary had a special love           
for family especially her grandchildren and      
great grandchildren and always made herself      
available to serve those in need, whether it     
was loaning a sensitive ear or providing         
prudent advice to those incarcerated and those   
in the community. It is well known amongst       
family, friends and colleagues, that Mary fed    
and housed hundreds of people down through       
the years. Mary loved sewing, fishing, playing   
computer games, gospel singing and most of       
all serving the Lord; and                        
     WHEREAS, both her parents, her              
husband, L.B. Swims, one brother, Charles B.     
Robinson, and one grandson, Anthony              
Maurice Swims and one granddaughter,             
Tracey Swims preceded her in death; and          
      WHEREAS, Mary leaves to cherish her        
beautiful memory, 6 loving and adoring           
children: Fannie (Milford) Graphenreed, L.C.,    
Deborah, Sylvia, Tracy, Sr., and Keyran, Sr.;    
3 sisters, Lacy McSwain, Helen Jones, and        
Fannie Thomas; 2 brothers, Henry (Mary           
Ann) Robinson and Willie (Lucille) Robinson;     
1 bother-in-law, six sister-in-laws, 20          
grandchildren, 35 great-grandchildren, a host    
great-great-grandchildren, special God-          
daughters, Velma Lofties, Earline Tharp, Stella  
Norise, and Carol Hardin and a host of other     
relatives, friends and entire church family.     
      NOW THEREFORE BE IT                        
RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen of             
the City of St. Louis that we pause to           
remember the many accomplishments and            
contributions of Mary Louise Swims to the        
citizens of the City of St. Louis and we join    
with her many friends in expressing our sorrow   
at her passing, and we further direct the Clerk  
of this Board to spread a copy of this           
Resolution across the minutes of these           
proceedings and to prepare a memorial copy       
for presentation to the Swims family, at a time  
and place deemed appropriate by the Sponsor.     
Introduced on the 26th day of August, 2011       
by:                                              
Honorable Frank Williamson,Alderman 26th Ward    
          Resolution No. 188                     
         Bertha Gilkey Bonds                     
      WHEREAS, we have been appraised            
that on Sunday, August 28, 2011 at the Polish    
Heritage Center, the Metro Sentinel Journal      
 News will convene its Jewels of the              
 Community Awards Ceremony; amd                   
       WHEREAS, under the leadership of           
 Michael C. Williams, owner and publisher,        
 the Metro Sentinel Journal News continues        
 to recognize the meaningful contributions of     
 stellar areas residents; and                     
      WHEREAS, this event recognizes              
 women who are strong advocates for law and       
 order, peace and justice; and                    
     WHEREAS, these women serve as role           
 models in the community; and                     
      WHEREAS, Bertha Gilkey Bonds is a           
 celebrated civil rights worker and world-        
 traveler. She is a consultant on housing for     
 senior and low-income residents Also, she is     
 the former president of Cochran Housing          
 Association.                                     
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT                        
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen for            
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our       
 deliberations to recognize Bertha Gilkey         
 Bonds for her stellar accomplishments and        
 commitment to making our region a better place   
 to live and work. We direct the Clerk of this    
 Board to prepare a commemorative copy of         
 this resolution to the end that may be           
 presented to our honoree at the time and place   
 deemed appropriate by the sponsor.               
 Introduced on the 26th day of August, 2011       
 by:                                              
 HonorableApril Ford-Griffin,Alderwoman 5th Ward  
           Resolution No. 189                     
           Judge Judy Draper                      
       WHEREAS, we have been appraised            
 that on Sunday, August 28, 2011 at the Polish    
 Heritage Center, the Metro Sentinel Journal      
 News will convene its Jewels of the              
 Community Awards Ceremony; and                   
       WHEREAS, under the leadership of           
 Michael C. Williams, owner and publisher,        
 the Metro Sentinel Journal News continues        
 to recognize the meaningful contributions of     
 stellar areas residents; and                     
      WHEREAS, this event recognizes              
 women who are strong advocates for law and       
 order, peace and justice; and                    
     WHEREAS, these women serve as role           
 models in the community; and                     
      WHEREAS, Judge Judy Draper is a             
 member of St. Louis County Circuit Courts.       
 She is known for being tough on crime and        
 recently received the coveted Theodore           
 McMillan Award.                                  
    NOW THEREFORE BE IT                           
 RESOLVED by the Board of Aldermen for            
 the City of St. Louis that we pause in our     
 deliberations to recognize Judge Judy Draper   
 for her stellar accomplishments and            
 commitment to making our region a better place 
 to live and work. We direct the Clerk of this  
 Board to prepare a commemorative copy of       
 this resolution to the end that may be         
 presented to our honoree at the time and place 
 deemed appropriate by the sponsor.

    Honorable Kacie Starr Triplett              
       WHEREAS, we have been appraised          
 that on Sunday, August 28, 2011 at the Polish  
 Heritage Center, the Metro Sentinel Journal    
 News will convene its Jewels of the            
 Community Awards Ceremony; and                 
       WHEREAS, under the leadership of         
 Michael C. Williams, owner and publisher,      
 the Metro Sentinel Journal News continues      
 to recognize the meaningful contributions of   
 stellar areas residents; and                   
      WHEREAS, this event recognizes            
 women who are strong advocates for law and     
 order, peace and justice; and                  
     WHEREAS, these women serve as role         
 models in the community; and                   
      WHEREAS, the Honorable Kacie Starr        
 Triplett is an up and coming politician in the 
 City of St. Louis. She represents the powerful 
 6th Ward and is being honored for high         
 achievement in politics.                       
       NOW THEREFORE BE IT
